text:
Q: How to destroy Tkinter windows from external script? A:

You can use signals or events to communicate between your main script and the external script. For example, you can use a threading event to signal the main script to close the windows.

GUI.py:

import threading
import tkinter as tk

class GUI:
    def __init__(self):
        self.root = tk.Tk()
        self.win = tk.Toplevel()
        self.shutdown_event = threading.Event()

        # Bind a key or button to trigger shutdown
        self.root.bind('<Escape>', lambda event: self.shutdown())

    def shutdown(self):
        self.shutdown_event.set()
        self.root.destroy()
        self.win.destroy()

    def run(self):
        while not self.shutdown_event.is_set():
            self.root.update()
            self.win.update()

# Your GUI code here
gui = GUI()
gui.run()

external_script.py:

from GUI import gui

gui.shutdown()

Q: Can System.Text.Json.Serialization detect long reference cycles? A:

Can System.Text.Json.Serialization detect long reference cycles?

Yes, System.Text.Json's ReferenceHandler.IgnoreCycles can detect and ignore arbitrarily deep reference cycles.

However JsonSerializerOptions.MaxDepth still applies so if the depth of a back-reference exceeds the maximum serialization nesting depth a JsonException with the message A possible object cycle was detected. will still be thrown. If you expect reference cycles to exceed the default MaxDepth (currently 64) you will need to increase it to account for your expected maximum serialization depth.

That being said, do not set MaxDepth to some very large value such as int.MaxValue. If you really were to try to serialize or deserialize a model with such an extreme nesting depth, System.Text.Json could end up throwing a StackOverflowException which cannot be caught with a try / catch block and will instead terminate your application -- which means your application would be vulnerable to denial-of-service bugs when passed an extremely deep model by an attacker. If you really do expect to have such deep nesting levels you may need to rethink your serialization format.

It looks like the issue may be with cycles that repeat classes, but not objects. These are all many-to-many relations and their mapping tables.
The question now becomes: is there a setting in the JSON serializer to ignore any instance of a class that has already been serialized?

Rather than ignoring instances of a class that have already been serialized, you may preserve references by setting JsonSerializerOptions.ReferenceHandler to ReferenceHandler.Preserve. As explained in How to preserve references and handle or ignore circular references in System.Text.Json:

To preserve references and handle circular references, set ReferenceHandler to Preserve. This setting causes the following behavior:

  • On serialize:

    When writing complex types, the serializer also writes metadata properties ($id, $values, and $ref).

  • On deserialize:

    Metadata is expected (although not mandatory), and the deserializer tries to understand it.

Do note that this option changes your JSON format. When an object is first encountered during serialization, an $id": "<some number>", property is included. Then if the object is again encountered during serialization, it isn't serialized; instead a single "$ref": "<some number>" property is serialized in its place.

For instance, if you have some very simple recursive model like this:

class Model { public Model? NestedModel { get; set; } }

And serialize an instance that has a back-reference at depth 3 with options:

JsonSerializerOptions options = new()
{
    ReferenceHandler = ReferenceHandler.Preserve,
    WriteIndented = true
};

The resulting JSON will look like:

 {
  "$id": "1",
  "NestedModel": {
    "$id": "2",
    "NestedModel": {
      "$id": "3",
      "NestedModel": {
        "$ref": "1" // The back reference to the root model.
      }
    }
  }
}

Demo fiddle here.

Q: How to find cube root using Python? A:

So I realise I am very late to the party but I see a load of mixed results from all of these answers. So I've made my own function which will be a little slower to run but unless using decimals, 100% accurate. It's pretty simple and easy to do yourself but I didn't see anything like on here so here:

t = 0 # input # will start from set value
z=36 # answer
x=6 #power
y=0 # do not touch
while y!=z:
    print(f"y = {y}")
    t+=1
    y=t+1
    h=y
    j=1
    while j<x:
        y=y*h
        j+=1
        if y>=z:
            break
print("finished:")

print(t)#could have wrote this output better but honestly I can't be bothered to change it.
print("to the power of")
print(x)
print("is")
print(y)

Q: How to perform arithmetic manipulations on numbers in Vim? A:

If the file format is pretty specific you could honestly get away with using a vimscript range function to do this

function! IncrementLinesBy(value) range
  for lnum in range(a:firstline, a:lastline)
    let line = getline(lnum)

    let num = line->trim()->str2float()
    let newLine = num + a:value
    call setline(lnum, newLine)
  endfor
endfunction

Select the lines you want to change with visual selection and then press : and then you can call the function by typing call IncrementLinesBy(1.23) which will produce :<,'>call IncrementLinesBy(1.23) in the execute line and bing bang boom it should work

    tool_calls = getattr(first, "tool_calls", None)

Q: Next.JS 15: "await cookies()" in server component called from client causes hanging A:

The hang happens because in Next.js 15 the new async cookies() API only works inside a valid request context. When you call getRole() from a client component, it triggers a new server action that no longer shares the original request scope, so the second await cookies() call has no active context and just stalls.

Next 15 expects cookies to be read inside server components or route handlers, not inside server actions that get invoked from client components. If you move your cookie read into a server component (or pass it down through props) instead of calling it twice through useEffect, the hanging problem disappears.

Q: In rust, is there an iterator adapter that can consume multiple (but not all) items before producing an output? A:

If you're open to using the itertools crate, it has .tuple_windows() which does what you want directly, or it has .batching() which has the more generic functionality you're after.

Q: Why training loss is increased at the beginning of each epoch? A:

It's now called the Epochal Sawtooth Phenomenon (ESP). A paper was published about this in June 2025: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11063-025-11776-4

Q: How to pick second value for same ID with Other Conditions A:

I'd use a window function to check if a MapID has an employee, then use the result to filter to just employee rows or non-employee rows.

Finally, it's just a pivot to move the two regions into primary and secondary.

CREATE TABLE Region
(
    MapID varchar(10),
    EmployeeID varchar(10),
    Zip5 varchar(10),
    Business Varchar(50),
    Region varchar(50)
);

INSERT INTO Region
    SELECT '9879', '100', Null,'B1', 'South'
    UNION
    SELECT '9879', '100', Null,'B2', 'South-1'
    UNION
    SELECT '9879', Null, '04987','B2', 'South-1'
    UNION
    SELECT '7890', '200', Null, 'B2','West S San Diago'
    UNION
    SELECT '7890', NULL, '45678','B1', 'West So. CA'
    UNION
    SELECT '7890', NULL, '45678', 'B2','West-1'
    UNION
    SELECT '5678', '400', Null,'B1', 'EastCentral'
    UNION
    SELECT '5678', '400', Null,'B2', 'Central-1'
    UNION
    SELECT '5678', Null, '56333','B1', 'EastCentral-1'
    UNION
    SELECT '5678', Null, '56333','B2', 'East-1'
;


WITH
  look_around AS
(
  SELECT
    *,
    MAX(EmployeeID) OVER (PARTITION BY MapID)   AS map_employee
  FROM
    Region
)
SELECT
  MapID,
  MAX(CASE WHEN Business = 'B2' THEN Region END) AS RegionPrimary,
  MAX(CASE WHEN Business = 'B1' THEN Region END) AS RegionSecondary
FROM
  look_around
WHERE
  EmployeeID = map_employee
  OR
  (
    map_employee IS NULL
    AND
    EmployeeID   IS NULL
  )
GROUP BY
  MapID
MapID RegionPrimary RegionSecondary
5678 Central-1 EastCentral
7890 West S San Diago null
9879 South-1 South

fiddle

It's not clear from your post when Business would ever be B1, so I haven't included that.

Q: Jakarta Persistence can't find Entity classes A:

Probably it's a compatibility error. Jakarta 3.2.0 was generated for Java 17+. If you're using Java 11, then the compiler won't be able to read the .class files inside the JAR.

You can check it here: https://jakarta.ee/specifications/persistence/3.2/ , on the section "Minimum Java SE Version".

Try using Jakarta 3.1.0 or another version that is compatible with JDK 11

Q: How can I jump to a bookmark in netrw? A:

The command for jumping to a bookmark is {cnt}gb (not {cnt}bm) in which {cnt} is a bookmark number. In normal mode:

gb     " jump to latest bookmark
2gb    " jump to bookmark number 2

You can see a list of bookmarks and their numbers with qb.

Q: Why does my Angular server table data pulled from an Observable from MongoDB database display only every other edit to the HTML file? A:

The behavior you’re seeing (table data sometimes showing, sometimes not, and only appearing after an HTML edit triggers a hot reload) usually means Angular is not running change detection on the component that sets your animals array.

This is almost always caused by providing the service in the component instead of globally.

The root issue

You’re doing this:

providers: [AnimalData]

When you put a service in providers inside a component, Angular creates a new instance of that service every time the component loads, and that breaks state sharing + change detection (especially in standalone components).

In dev mode with ng serve, hot reload causes Angular to reuse or destroy parts of the tree differently, making the data “randomly appear” depending on when Angular happens to re-run the component.

Fix

Remove providers: [AnimalData] from the component

@Component({
  selector: 'app-animal-listing',
  standalone: true,
  imports: [CommonModule],
  templateUrl: './animal-listing.html',
  styleUrl: './animal-listing.css'
})
export class AnimalListing implements OnInit { … }

Make sure your service uses a global provider

In AnimalData:

@Injectable({
  providedIn: 'root'
})
export class AnimalData {
  …
}

This ensures you have one shared instance, and Angular’s normal change detection updates your template.

Why this fixes it

  • Angular wasn’t updating the template because the service instance that performed the HTTP request wasn’t the same instance Angular expected from dependency injection.

  • Removing the local provider makes Angular use the root service → stable state → consistent rendering.

  • Hot reloads made it look random because Vite/HMR alters how Angular mounts components.

(Minor issue) Also fix improper Angular metadata key

You wrote:

styleUrl: './animal-listing.css'

But the property is styleUrls, plural:

styleUrls: ['./animal-listing.css']

This does not break the table, but it can cause Angular to partially reload the component, masking the real issue.

Q: How to print a Hollow cude A:

You could do something like this:

rows = 5
cols = 10

cube = (
    '*' * cols + '\n'
    + (
        '*' + ' ' * (cols - 2) + '*\n'
    ) * (rows - 2)
    + '*' * cols
)
print(cube)

Disclaimer: I did not test this.

Q: How to solve "RuntimeError: CUDA error: invalid device ordinal"? A:

Run nvidia-smi in the Terminal and see how many GPU:s you have a choice about, should be just 1.

Q: Java UUID generation (name-based, predictable) A:

Caveat: I just threw this code together roughly. Not tested. Use at our own risk.

Ignore the accepted Answer

The accepted Answer is incorrect.

Versions 3 & 5 UUID
[your input] ⇒ [hash calculation] ⇒ [UUID bits arrangement] ⇒ [UUID value]
UUID uuid = UUID.nameUUIDFromBytes( yourInputAsBytes );

The entire point of Version 3 and Version 5 name-based UUID is that, given the same inputs (namespace and name), you get the very same UUID output. The process is deterministic, repeatable. Contrary to that other Answer, there is no “blending in” of information from the local machine.

By the way, “name-based” is bit of a misnomer. Some folks refer to these two Versions of UUID more descriptively as “hash-based”.

Example code

Define your namespace. Here we use DNS domain name owned by our company.

final String domainName = "awesome-app.basil.work";

You may want to make this a static final constant in your app(s) for re-use.

Define the “name” for the object you want to generate a UUID.

For example, say we want to identify products in this Java record class:

public record Product( UUID id , String partNo , String vendorCode , String name ){}

Example data:

String partNo = "223-612-3";
String vendorCode = "TacomaScrew";
String productName = "M6-1.0 X 12 Mm Metric Socket Head Cap Screws - Class 12.9, Zinc, Coarse 100/PKG";

We want to use values that are stable, that will not be changing over time, for a reproducible UUID value. So we likely do not want to use name of the product. Such product titles are likely to change on occasion. Instead we want to use only the part number and the vendor code. Those should never change. And together those should never collide.

String name = partNo + venderCode ;  // Ignoring product name.

Concatenate the namespace and name.

String namespaceAndName = domainName + name ;

Convert that to an array of bytes. Tip: Specify a charset explicitly to ensure that you always convert to the exact same byte values. The entire point here is to use the very same namespace across all the places where you generate the UUIDs.

byte[] bytes = namespaceAndName.getBytes( StandardCharsets.UTF_8 );

Generate a Version 3 UUID using the UUID class bundled with Java, the java.util.UUID class. When we submit our array of byte values, this function hashes those per the MD5 standard. Every proper implementation of MD5 hash-generation will produce the very same output when given the very same input. After truncation, those bits are used as our UUID save for the four Version and two Variant bits defined (hard-coded) by the UUID standard.

UUID uuid = UUID.nameUUIDFromBytes( bytes );

Now we can assemble our Product record object.

Product productScrew = new Product ( uuid , partNo , vendorCode , productName ) ;

We can generate text in standard canonical format to represent the 128-bits value of our UUID.

String uuidHexAndDash = uuid.toString() ;  // The "hex-and-dash" string format defined by RFC 9562.

For your copy-and-paste convenience, here is the entire example.

final String domainName = "awesome-app.basil.work";

String partNo = "223-612-3";
String vendorCode = "TacomaScrew";
String productName = "M6-1.0 X 12 Mm Metric Socket Head Cap Screws - Class 12.9, Zinc, Coarse 100/PKG";

String name = partNo + vendorCode;  // Ignoring the product name.
String namespaceAndName = domainName + name;
byte[] bytes = namespaceAndName.getBytes( StandardCharsets.UTF_8 );

UUID uuid = UUID.nameUUIDFromBytes( bytes );
String uuidHexAndDash = uuid.toString();  // The "hex-and-dash" string format defined by RFC 9562.

IO.println( "bytes = " + Arrays.toString( bytes ) );
IO.println( uuidHexAndDash );

bytes = [97, 119, 101, 115, 111, 109, 101, 45, 97, 112, 112, 46, 98, 97, 115, 105, 108, 46, 119, 111, 114, 107, 50, 50, 51, 45, 54, 49, 50, 45, 51, 84, 97, 99, 111, 109, 97, 83, 99, 114, 101, 119]

ff54ffdf-aff5-34b0-b64f-7e631eacf694

Notice how every time you input that particular domain name, part number, and vendor code, you always get the very same UUID generated.

By the way, the above discussion is a simplistic approach that works well enough for in-house use only of the UUIDs. If instead you intend for these UUIDs to circulate on the Internets or amongst the public, then you should more formally define your “namespace” as a UUID to be registered with the IANA. See discussion in the standard, RFC 9562. You would change the above code like this:

UUID namespaceUuid = UUID.nameUUIDFromBytes( domainName.getBytes( StandardCharsets.UTF_8 ) ) ;  // Register this UUID with the IANA to avoid collisions. 

byte[] nameBytes = name.getBytes( StandardCharsets.UTF_8 ) ;
ByteBuffer bb = ByteBuffer.allocate( 16 + nameBytes.length );
bb.putLong( uuid.getMostSignificantBits() );
bb.putLong( uuid.getLeastSignificantBits() );
bb.put( nameBytes ) ;
byte[] bytes = bb.array();

UUID uuid = UUID.nameUUIDFromBytes( bytes );

Your questions

You said:

Does that mean the UUID will be different when generated on another machine?

No. Same inputs get the same output, generating the very same UUID.

Again, the entire point of Version 3 & 5 UUID is to get the same UUID from the the same inputs. If you have one namespace and one name on a machine in Paris, and a machine in Casablanca has the same namespace and the same name, they will both generate the exact same UUID. The only coordination needed between the machines is that must both be informed ahead of time as to the chosen namespace value. And the machines must agree on what fields of data to use as the “name”.

Hashing

Version 3 & 5 UUID run your inputs (namespace and name) through a hashing algorithm to generate an arbitrary but deterministic value. The hash value is too long for a UUID, so some bits are truncated. This truncation raises the chances of a duplicate, but not practically so for common purposes. The truncated bits are then laid as the bits of the new UUID except for six semantic bits required by the UUID specification to identity UUID Version and Variant. And, voilà, you have your predictably generated UUID.

Version 5 is the exact same as Version 3 but swaps out MD5 to instead use the more modern SHA-1 hashing algorithm. MD5 has some flaws, and is not as cryptographically-strong as SHA-1. But, (a) The java.util.UUID class in Java does not provide for generation of Version 5 UUIDs, and (b) if your business domain does not have security concerns regarding the generation of these UUIDs, then Version 3 works well enough. If you really want Version 5, obtain a third-party UUID generating library or roll your own.

You said:

What is the best way to generate UUIDs such that when obj1.equals(obj2) == true, then uuid1.equals(uuid2) == true

If you really want that… Whatever fields you compare in your implementation of the override of Object#equals must be used as the name fed into the Version 3 or 5 UUID generator.

So we really should change the example record class used in example code above. In our UUID generation, we examined only two of the three fields on that record, setting aside the fourth field of UUID id. To meet your exact requirement of:

obj1.equals(obj2) == true, then uuid1.equals(uuid2) == true

… we need to add overrides to our record for equals and hashCode.

public record Product( UUID id, String partNo, String vendorCode, String name ) {
    @Override
    public boolean equals( Object o ) {
        if ( this == o ) return true;
        if ( o == null || getClass() != o.getClass() ) return false;
        Product product = (Product) o;
        return Objects.equals( this.partNo, product.partNo ) &&
               Objects.equals( this.vendorCode, product.vendorCode );
    }

    @Override
    public int hashCode() {
        return Objects.hash( this.partNo, this.vendorCode );
    }
}

You commented:

reason I am not using the fields (that matter for equality) directly is because my objects have dozens of fields and concatenating them to create a uuid will result in a String that's way too long. Hashing such a string might be the solution

Hashing is exactly what the Version 3 or 5 UUID generator does for you!

So, no, the string you pass as the name for the UUID will not be too long. The hashing algorithm always produces a result of a certain number of bits regardless of how long was the input. If you do not understand that, study up on hashing at Wikipedia etc.

Versions of UUID

RFC 9562 of year 2024 supersedes RFC 4122. The specification is entirely rewritten. Now much clearer, and easier to read and understand.

RFC 9562 clarifies the existing Versions 1-5, and defines three more: 6, 7, and 8. Versions 6 & 7 are engineered to be index-friendly, for optimized performance in databases.

Version Basis Index
friendly		 Notes
2 DCE Security UUIDs — Obsolete.
4 Random ❌ 122 of the 128 bits come from random number generator.
3 & 5 Hash calculated from your input ❌ Predictable: Same input always renders the same UUID value.

Versions 3 & 5 are exactly the same except swapping older MD5 hash algorithm for SHA-1. Prefer 5 over 3 generally, but both are valid.

The UUID class built into Java 5 through Java 25 can generate 3 but not 5. To generate Version 5 UUIDs, add a third-party UUID-generation library to your project. Or write your own UUID generator with SHA-1 hash calculation.
1 & 6 Point in space and time: MAC address or something similar, plus timestamp. 1 ❌
6 ✅		 V. 1 has screwy kind of timestamp, and has screwy layout of bits that are hostile to indexing. V. 6 has same screwy timestamp but fixes the bits layout to be index friendly.

V. 6 also advises against using actual MAC address for security, privacy, and practical concerns.

Versions 1 & 6 UUID values can be converted back-and-forth losslessly. (same bits, different arrangement)
7 Timestamp + Random ✅ Uses common Unix-style timestamp. Bit layout is sensible, to be index-friendly.

Version 7 should be your default Version of choice, unless you have specific reason to use another Version.
8 Unspecified ❓ For experimental or private use. Not for general circulation or publication.

Q: How to run a bash command until it is successful or a timeout is reached? A:

NOTE: This answer does what OP's example code suggests he wants: sleep an increasing length of time after each attempt. This is likely not what most are looking for.

You can simplify things a bit by putting command right in the test and doing increments a bit differently. Otherwise the script looks fine:

NEXT_WAIT_TIME=0
until (( NEXT_WAIT_TIME == 5 )) || cmd; do
    sleep "$(( NEXT_WAIT_TIME++ ))"
done
(( NEXT_WAIT_TIME < 5 ))

Q: XCUITest in simulator clone doesn't send to request to server and seems to cache network responses A:

Going through and testing all of my assumptions, I found the reason for everything. It would have been easy to find if I could see the NSLog/console output from the app during the test, but since it's not visible with parallel UITests, the fact that it was hitting the wrong URL was not readily apparent.

We have code in our network API that determines whether it's running in a simulator or not and chooses which URL to use based on that. In the sim, it is supposed to hit our local test server, but when not in the sim, it should hit our production server.

It turns out that the sim-clones used by the XCUITests are different enough from the normal simulators that our code didn't think it was running in a sim and so it was hitting the prod server.

Which explains why it was getting a response even when I shut down our local test server... and why it got the old message when I changed the message on our local test server... etc.

I updated our simulator-detection code and it finally started hitting our local test server.

Q: Can I have a reference to a variable while still allowing that variable to be mutated in Rust? A:

Interior mutability seems like best fit.

This particular issue however, can also be solved by an API like fn borrow_id_generator<'a>(&'a mut IdGenerator) -> IdGeneratorBorrow<'a>, then IdGeneratorBorrow<'a> produce references with lifetime 'a.

Q: Need help running a code in google antigravity A:

Switching from Visual Studio to a lightweight IDE like VS Code (or Google AI Ultra) can feel weird because you now compile and run manually. Here’s the easiest way:

Make sure MinGW is installed and in your PATH:

gcc --version

Compile your C code (main.c):

gcc main.c -o main.exe

Run it:

./main.exe

or just main.exe on Windows.

Optional in VS Code:

  • Install C/C++ extension.

  • Add tasks.json to build and launch.json to debug.

  • Then Ctrl+Shift+B builds and F5 runs like VS.

Common issues:

  • “.exe doesn’t exist” → you didn’t compile yet or folder is wrong.

  • PATH not set → gcc/gdb not found.

  • Wrong workspace folder → IDE can’t see your file.

Tip: Try manual compile → run first. Once it works, set up IDE tasks so “Run” behaves like Visual Studio.

Q: How to pick second value for same ID with Other Conditions A:

This doesn't need any window functions at all, you can do it purely with normal aggregation functions.

SELECT
  r.MapID,
  MIN(CASE WHEN r.Business = 'B2' THEN r.Business END) AS Business,
  CASE WHEN COUNT(r.EmployeeID) > 0
    THEN
      MIN(CASE WHEN r.EmployeeID IS NOT NULL AND r.Business = 'B2' THEN r.Region END)
    ELSE
      MIN(CASE WHEN r.Zip5 IS NOT NULL AND r.Business = 'B2' THEN r.Region END)
    END AS Region,
  CASE WHEN COUNT(r.EmployeeID) > 0
    THEN
      MIN(CASE WHEN r.EmployeeID IS NOT NULL AND r.Business = 'B1' THEN r.Region END)
    ELSE
      MIN(CASE WHEN r.Zip5 IS NOT NULL AND r.Business = 'B1' THEN r.Region END)
    END AS SecondaryRegion
FROM #Region r
GROUP BY
  r.MapID;

What we are doing here is:

  • for each MapID, we are checking whether there are any EmployeeID (that's the COUNT).
  • if yes then use conditional aggregation to look for the row where EmployeeID is non-null and Business is B1 or B2 resp., then return the Region for that row.
  • if not then do the same aggregation but look for a non-null Zip5 row instead.
  • As mentioned by others, it's not clear when Business should ever not be B2.

db<>fiddle

Q: How to get a status code from this curl command A:

As chat gpt said this command doesn't give the 200 OK code in terminal, but it can give it if modified a little bit.

This one to write code and many other data:

curl -i -X PUT https://delegated-ipfs.dev/routing/v1/ipns/<name-in-mbase36> -H "Content-Type: application/vnd.ipfs.ipns-record" --data-binary @record.bin

This one to write only code:

curl -w "%{http_code}" -X PUT https://delegated-ipfs.dev/routing/v1/ipns/<name-in-mbase36> -H "Content-Type: application/vnd.ipfs.ipns-record" --data-binary @record.bin

Q: Why doesn't R2DBC support features like lazy loading, cascading operations, or dirty checking, which are available in JPA? A:

Because you are comparing a database driver standard to a standard for how applications should communicate with a database.

A more correct comparison is to compare the JDBC driver standard to the R2DBC standard. Which is basically standards for how a driver should communicate with a database.

JPA is a standard that is built on top of JDBC. And there is no such standard built ontop of R2DBC.

Hibernate for instance is a implementation of the JPA standard, which means hibernate uses JDBC under the hood. JDBC is blocking which means JPA is blocking since it is built ontop. Which also means we cant use JPA with R2DBC.

The problems is like always to get companies to agree on a standard. Remember R2DBC is a database driver specification that was defined by pivotal (Spring). Just convincing all public databases to write completely new drivers using this new specification was a feat itself.

A driver can be very complicated and time consuming and costly to implement. Imagen what a complete ORM framework would take to implement?

RedHats hibernate has implemented hibernate-reactive, but as for now there is no "JPA-reactive" standard, which means there is no agreed upon solution for how to tackle that.

If you can define a spec and get all companies to agree on that spec then there might be one, but remember the first JPA spec came back in 2006, almost 20 years ago. Its hard get people to get along.

Q: How to prevent Git from commiting Jupyter Notebook results? A:

This is what I use:

Change .git/hooks/pre-commit to contain:

#!/bin/sh
# Remove all Jupyter notebook outputs before committing

# Ensure nbstripout is installed
if ! command -v nbstripout >/dev/null 2>&1; then
    echo "nbstripout not found. Install with: pip install nbstripout"
    exit 1
fi

# Strip outputs from all staged notebooks
for file in $(git diff --cached --name-only -- '*.ipynb'); do
    echo "Stripping outputs from $file"
    nbstripout "$file"
    git add "$file"
done

exit 0

Then make sure to change the file to executable by running the follwing:
chmod +x .git/hooks/pre-commit

Then activate it by running:

nbstripout --intall

And then finally when you go to push your code, you should see that the output has been stripped from any files you are pushing.

Hope this helps.

Q: Shutdown all Running Virtual Machines and starting auto-start machines again A:

I had the same problem and so I made a small if statement to check the /var/log/libvirt/qemu/domain.com.log to see whether reason=shutdown was issued in the logs, which serves as a proxy for whether the domain actually shutdown or not. If the conditional fails, the script will email you, and if it succeeds, the conditional will continue with your backup script and/or call another. It is also provisioned for a loop/array with multiple VMs. Something like this should work:

#!/bin/bash
DATE=`date +"%Y%m%d-%H:%M:%S"`
IMG="guest1.qcow2 guest2.qcow2"

for i in $IMG;
do
virsh shutdown $i
#Adjust to what you expect is a reasonable shutdown time
sleep 2m

if
tail -n -2 /var/log/libvirt/qemu/$i.log | grep "reason=shutdown"
then

#enter your backup script inline here, or call it
/bin/bash /usr/local/bin/backup-script.sh

else
#notify of failure
echo "The VM failed to shutdown or is already off at $(date) so I can't run your backup script" | mail -s "[backup-failed]-$(hostname -f)-$(date)" alert@domain.com

fi
done

No script is perfect and you will still need to conduct regular maintenance to ensure that it runs properly. I will also note that my solution is quite primitive, but that it works reliably. For passerby, however, I will note that the OP question seems to be a duplicate to this question which has some very elegant proposals as to how to ensure and/or wait for your VMs to power down before executing scripts on them. I have a different script based off one of those here if it helps passerby.

Q: ModuleNotFoundError when importing module from local package after pip install -e in Python project A:

Let's put us all on the same footing by using MyBinder to demonstrate. That will eliminate the 'works on my machine' cases.

The issue is usually that even though you run the command pip install -e ., it isn't necessarily running where Jupyter is looking. If you already have the Jupyter working, often the easiest thing is to install it from inside your working Jupyter using the magic %pip install command so that it ensures you install to where the kernel backing your active notebook is running.

Two step-by-step demonstrations you can try yourself without touching your local machine, installing anything on your machine, or signing up for anything:

Demonstration OPTION #1

I forked you demonstration and added one of these to be launched via MyBinder.

Go to the fork here and get started by press the 'launch binder' badge.

In that active session, you'll see I first advise you to run the following:

%pip install -e .

The % in front of the pip command is very important when running inside Jupyter.

The magic pip command variation was added in 2019 to ensure the install occurs in the environment where the kernel is running that backs the active notebook.
See more about the modern %pip install command here.

Let that run and then when it finishes...
IMPORTANT. RESTART THE KERNEL!!!

Now in a new cell in that notebook, you can run your import command:

from quant_utils.data import download_data

That works! No error this time.

If you start a fresh session, you can see that as you saw, directly running from quant_utils.data import download_data fails with the error you saw. (You can indeed run from src.quant_utils.data import download_data; however, you'd still need to install the other packages as it wouldn't have handled installing according to your project .toml.)

You could add uv into this mix as others have suggested; however, then you still need to insure the correct environment.

Demonstration OPTION #2

For the second demonstration, you can use a session launched via MyBinder without your content already present.

Alternative Demonstration that SKIPS THE GIT CLONING

Another way that will work to use the magic pip install to install direct from your repo:

%pip install git+https://github.com/ImSeekingAlpha/Quant-trading-journey.git

To demonstrate that:

Go here and hit the 'launch binder' badge. (Or just click here to launch a session in your browser.)

That will bring up a session without the content present in any manner. Essentially a blank Jupyter session that doesn't know about your repo.

Open a new notebook and run the following:

%pip install git+https://github.com/ImSeekingAlpha/Quant-trading-journey.git

Let that run and then when it finishes...
Restart the kernel.

Make a new cell in that notebook and then run

from quant_utils.data import download_data

That will work without error.

Q: Why don't logical operators (&& and ||) always return a boolean result? A:

In JavaScript, both || and && are logical short-circuit operators that return the first fully-determined “logical value” when evaluated from left to right.

In expression X || Y, X is first evaluated, and interpreted as a boolean value. If this boolean value is true, then it is returned. And Y is not evaluated. (Because it doesn’t matter whether Y is true or Y is false, X || Y has been fully determined.) That is the short-circuit part.

If this boolean value is false, then we still don’t know if X || Y is true or false until we evaluate Y, and interpret it as a boolean value as well. So then Y gets returned.

And && does the same, except it stops evaluating if the first argument is false.

The first tricky part is that when an expression is evaluated as true, then the expression itself is returned. Which counts as true in logical expressions, but you can also use it. So this is why you are seeing actual values being returned.

The second tricky part is that when an expression is evaluated as false, then in JS 1.0 and 1.1 the system would return a boolean value of false; whereas in JS 1.2 on it returns the actual value of the expression.

In JS false, 0, -0, "", null, undefined, NaN and document.all all count as false.

Q: Is it safe to call fscanf after EOF? A:

@NooneAtAll3, "Do I have to check for EOF in the returns after each one" -->
Yes. Otherwise you may miss an input error.

Input functions return EOF for 3 reasons:

  • End-of-file flag is set.

  • End-of-file is just been detected. This also sets the stream's end-of-file flag.

  • Input error detected like reading from stdout, writing to stdin or reading a parity or mechanical/communication error. This also sets the stream's error flag.

Note that EOF is not returned just because the error flag is set.

Since OP mentioned "several fscanf attempts per line", a better approach is to read a line, perhaps with fgets() and then parse it, maybe with sprintf(). This separates input issues, like end-of-file and input error from parsing/grammar issues.

fgets() and fscanf("%_some_width_[^\n]%n", buf, &length) are building blocks to a good way to read a line. Yet C, unfortunately, lacks a really good standard way to read an entire line and then form a string in a supplied buffer.

Q: Copy lines that match a pattern within a range in nvim A:

If I use this command, it only get[s] the last matching line

'<,'>g/z_image/y

This is because the command overwrites the unnamed register with the :yank command.

The minimal tweak needed to make this work is to use a named register in its upper-case form which appends to the register, as explained in :help quote_alpha.

You need to make sure the register is empty before you start appending to it. The fastest way to clear a register is to record an empty macro to it.

The following sequence of commands will populate register v with the lines in question and put them:

qvq
:g/z_image/y V
"vp

By the way, the unnamed register is updated whenever a named register is. Inserting can also be done with a simple p or :put. Personally, I prefer to call registers by their name but there's really no need to.

Regarding this statement from your self-answer:

If you don’t want to alter the original text [...]

... then you still have some tricks up your sleeve:

  • yank and put to a temporary, or scratch buffer, alter the text there.
  • alter the text anyway and hit u to undo until it's back in its original shape.
  • alter the text anyway and abandon your changes with :q! or :e!.

Vim is a text editor, its purpose is to alter text. Using it according to its purpose yields the best results.

Q: Why do my goroutines see stale or repeated keys when ranging over a map and modifying it at the same time? A:

In most languages, map iterators are implemented to scan the buckets in their storage order, skipping those that don't hold a KV pair.

Changing the set of keys (by insertion or deletion) can trigger re-hashing , meaning that all the KV pairs get assigned new bucket numbers. But iterator cannot know that, since it only records the current bucket index.

As an example of a different approach, Linux directory inodes maintain both a hashing structure and a linked list, making it possible for getdents (and thus readdir) to return consistent results even if the directory changes while it is being read. (This is why lseek returns seemingly random values on directory filedescriptors.)

Array iterators likewise simply track the index they're up to. This means that inserting elements can cause other elements to be repeated by an iterator, and deleting elements can cause other elements to be missed by an iterator.

Q: Can any IDE check undefined variable in empty function in PHP? A:

In PHP, empty($undefined) is a correct expression and does not generate warns/errors even if the variable is undefined. To statically diagnose undefined variables, you can use $undefined == false or a custom empty function is_empty($undefined) instead. Or use a diff checker to check the changes made by AI.

Q: What happens when I take in &str with AsRef<Path>? A:

How can a reference to str be converted to a reference to Path ?

Simple cast. Those structures have exactly the same representation under the hood. The distinction exists purely for the static typing purposes. To indicate the usage.

Note however, that there's no guarantee that this will hold in the future. That's why AsRef exists, to encapsulate potential deviation in the implementation in the future. Basically, even if those structures become different in the future, the AsRef tells us that they will always be close enough to each other.

And in general does AsRef guarantee that there's no allocation involved?

No, there's absolutely no way to guarantee that allocation won't happen. Not for AsRef or any other piece of code. We can only expect certain behavior, but cannot guarantee it.

In the case of AsRef we expect as_ref to be a lightweight operation, without any allocation. Something like a pointer offset + cast.

And considering that it accepts and returns a (immutable) ref, it would be rather difficult for it to allocate and return the allocated ref. What would own that returned piece of memory? Lifetimes have to match. So the only possibility is to store it on the struct or make it static. Either way this means cells (lazy initialization?) and/or unsafe code. Possible, but I think against expectations.

Q: Why doesn’t TypeScript infer null in my function’s return type? A:

My Dear Champ,

In my knowledge the problem is simple but getting on your nerves, Hence:

The reason TypeScript is ignoring null in your inferred return type is your tsconfig.json configuration.

Specifically, you have set "strict": false.

The Technical Explanation

When "strict" is set to false, a specific sub-setting called strictNullChecks defaults to false.

In this mode, null and undefined are considered valid values for every type. TypeScript does not distinguish between T and T | null. Therefore, when it infers the return type, it collapses the union { object } | null into simply { object }, because under these settings, an object type implicitly includes null anyway.

How to Fix It

You have two options:

Option 1: Enable Strict Mode (Recommended)

This is the standard best practice for modern TypeScript projects. It will force you to handle nulls safely throughout your app.

Update your tsconfig.json:

JSON

{
  "compilerOptions": {
    // ... other options
    "strict": true
  }
}

Note: This might reveal other type errors in your project that were previously suppressed.

Option 2: Enable Only strictNullChecks

If turning on full strict mode causes too many errors right now, you can enable just this specific check:

JSON

{
  "compilerOptions": {
    // ... other options
    "strict": false,
    "strictNullChecks": true
  }
}

Verification

Once you change this setting and restart your TypeScript server (or VS Code), the inferred type will correctly update to:

TypeScript

{ labels: string[]; activeStep: number } | null

Would you like me to explain how to safely handle the potential null return value in your components once you enable strict mode?

Do tell me !

Q: How to switch active windows, in the command line, on OS X A:

Well answering a 10 year old question because it appears to be a popular unanswered question.

I had the same task for a MacOS script that needed to make some window active.

I see 2 solutions:

Option 1; Alt-tab back to the terminal

Since open moves the focus to the explorer, the previous window will still be your terminal.

We can useAppleScript to perform the Alt-tab, witch can be called from PHP with osascript:

<?php

$osa_alt_tab = <<<EOS
osascript -e 'tell application "System Events"' \
          -e 'key down command' \
          -e 'keystroke tab' \
          -e 'key up command' \
          -e 'end tell'
EOS;

shell_exec($osa_alt_tab);

Call this after some delay after calling open.

Option 2; Use applescript to open application by name

If alt-tabbing may cause some other screen to focus, applescript also alowes us to active a window by name, so assuming your using the native macOs terminal (no Iterm or such), use the following:

<?php

$osa_terminal = 'osascript -e \'tell application "Terminal" to activate\'';
shell_exec($osa_terminal);

You can replace "Terminal" with the name of the application you want the focus to go to, eg, "Microsoft Teams" or "Iterm2".

Q: Functional pattern, good or bad? A:

My take on this is to write my code for the most part in a class free object oriented (CFOO) fashion, where I use factory functions to create Objects ('constructors') which may or may not use other 'constructors' (factories).

It served me well the last few years. I am seldom bothered by the hassle of this and am able to keep instance members private using closures.

Furthermore I try to split up my code as much as possible to dedicated small functions, pure when possible.

Here's an interesting read on 'clean code'.

Here's something I wrote on the subject of CFOO (including an example).

Here's an example of a complete ticktock-library I created using CFOO.

Q: Run batch file as a Windows service A:

nssm can also register batch files as Windows services (which, for example, regularly write something to a log file), but...

  • The default setting is that when the service program terminates, it is restarted.
  • The restart occurs with an adjustable delay. During this delay, the service is displayed as “paused.”
  • If the batch file runs for less than approx. 3 seconds, an error occurs when the service is started (even though it was executed). It is therefore suboptimal to insist that a batch file running for 100 ms will be executed again in X seconds. Although this works initially, after a certain time it only happens about every 2 minutes!
  • The optimal solution would be for the batch file to simply run continuously in a loop with a wait time in between.
  • However, wait times in bat files are only possible via external commands (e.g., “timeout 3,” choice, ping, etc.). This means that a wait time process is active for a few seconds at a time and is displayed in the Task Manager. The alternative is to program a loop that simply compares the time. However, this has the disadvantage of permanently utilizing a CPU core. It's a choice between a rock and a hard place... Conclusion: Batch files are only suitable for use with nssm to a limited extent.

Q: Server-side autocomplete for ~1200 schools in Supabase/Postgres — need typo/acronym-tolerant, low resource usage A:

"~1200 schools (...) full client-side matching isn’t possible in the school search" - I agree with @RichardHuxton above that you may have discarded that option too early. 1200 strings is so little Postgres might not even bother optimising your queries, just seq-scan the heap at you because on default settings assuming weak to average IO capabilities, that's still too easy to fetch. Grab the first 20 to load the page, load the rest in the background and you should be able to easily handle this client-side.

Be sure to collect what search attempts led to what selection - that may let you expand your dictionary of common abbreviations and/or misspellings.

As to how you'd do that if you dealt with way more data, the economy package includes fuzzystrmatch and pg_trgm. You can upgrade that with full text search but only if you're sure the strings are stemmable, which I think, as mostly proper nouns, only some of them will be. The premium package is pgvector, which can handle not just typos based on character-level proximity, but semantic similarity search, coming up with 'College of the Redwoods' to someone typing 'Academy of Sequoias'.
Since JavaScript is notorious for its package/library repository bloat, I'm sure each of these has at least a few JS/TS/ES equivalents, to do the exact same thing client-side.

Q: Is there a mysql JDBC that will respect fetchSize? A:

NOTE: This answer is outdated due to changes in the driver implementation; refer to the answer by lxgr for a more up-to-date state of things.

Technically questions asking for libraries are off-topic. That said, as far as I know there is no alternative driver for MySQL. You either have the choice between getting all rows which might lead to out of memory situations, or to have the driver fetch them on demand by setting setFetchSize(Integer.MIN_VALUE).

The reason for this - as I understand from the Connector/J implementation notes - is that the MySQL protocol cannot have more than one cursor open per connection, therefor it defaults to streaming all rows to the client on execute.

The other option is that rows are retrieved one-by-one, but this comes with the problem that you cannot execute other statements on the same connection while processing the ResultSet:

There are some caveats with this approach. You must read all of the rows in the result set (or close it) before you can issue any other queries on the connection, or an exception will be thrown.

So the MySQL only has the option to get everything or to get one at a time. This means that there is no way for a driver to respect a different fetch size. And due to the caveats when getting one-by-one they opted to use the Integer.MIN_VALUE (instead of simply 1) as a signal that you should really think before doing this.

A possible 'in-between' solution would require you to program this yourself using LIMIT and OFFSET and repeatedly executing queries.

apply plugin: 'com.google.firebase.crashlytics'

Q: Filtering-out URL parameter on HTML page before they are sent to analytics A:

You can remove sensitive URL parameters without reloading the page by using the History API. This updates the URL before analytics scripts read it.

This keeps the page loaded but changes the address bar to:

https://my-web-page.com?code=123

So analytics will receive the cleaned URL.

Q: How to upgrade a .Net 4.8 project up to .NET 8.0? A:

I have migrate .net 4.8 into .NET 8.0 3 projects last year, it is never a smooth ride. There are many aspects we need to look into it.

Is your existing .net project a Web Application or a Web project.

If it is a web project, there is an option of "Convert to Web Application" from the Project Menu, you will get some boost in migration.

Next question would be, is your existing project in MVC technology or more in .aspx & aspx.cs forms, then you need to plan to convert your project in MVC, as it makes life quite easier in migration.

If your existing project is too complicated to make any more changes, it's better to start a fresh project (s) in .net 8.0 or latest version.

Following any architecture makes life much easier, if I can see some sample code or project structure it will be easier to suggest for migration.

I must say my migration journey was so helpful for me to learn & implement in latest technologies of .net 8.0.

I will be happy to help any further, if you have any specific scenario which is precenting you to move towards your migration.

Q: Get Screen resolution using WMI/powershell in Windows 7 A:

You can grab this from the Win32_VideoController WMI class. The VideoModeDescription property includes the screen resolution and the color depth.

(Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_VideoController).VideoModeDescription;

Result

1600 x 900 x 4294967296 colors

Q: A command to display a a key's randomart image from a fingerprint? A:

Using process substitution, you can also do:

ssh-keygen -lvf <(cat /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key.pub)
                    # ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
                    # |- or your desired public key

or, in modern versions of ssh-keygen (i think):

cat /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key.pub | ssh-keygen -lvf -
#   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^                   ^
#   |- or your desired public key                       |- this indicates stdin

Q: 32x32 icons for rich text editor? A:

You should look into the Tango Icon Library, it looks great and it's into the public domain (as noted in their FAQ).

The have the same icons in 16x16, 32x32 and 64x64 but they also gave you the svg source, so, you can easily get any dimensions you want exporting them with Inkscape

You can also use the LGPL Crystal Clear as recommended by cobbal.

set(CMAKE_AUTORCC ON)

When I added it, images loaded fine.

Q: An error occurred while preparing SDK package NDK (Side by side) 29.0.14206865: Not in GZIP format A:

Answer

The error:

An error occurred while preparing SDK package Android Emulator: Not in GZIP format

means that Android Studio downloaded a corrupted emulator archive:

emulator-darwin_aarch64-xxxxxxx.zip

This usually happens on macOS (M1/M2/M3) when the SDK Manager stores an incomplete download in its cache.

✅ Solution

You need to delete the corrupted files from the SDK cache and let Android Studio download them again.

1. Open your Android SDK directory

In my case the SDK path was:

/Users/USERNAME/Library/Android/sdk

You can check yours in:

Android Studio → Settings → Appearance & Behavior → System Settings → Android SDK
(Path is shown at the top.)

2. Delete cached downloads

Remove everything inside these two folders:

~/Library/Android/sdk/temp/
~/Library/Android/sdk/.cache/

If .cache is hidden, reveal hidden files in Finder with:

Command + Shift + .

Or via terminal:

rm -rf ~/Library/Android/sdk/temp/*
rm -rf ~/Library/Android/sdk/.cache/*

3. Reinstall the Android Emulator

Open:

Android Studio → Settings → Android SDK → SDK Tools

Disable Android Emulator → Apply
Then enable Android Emulator → Apply again.

Or install via terminal:

cd ~/Library/Android/sdk/cmdline-tools/latest/bin
./sdkmanager --install "emulator"

Q: Technique to measure GPU utilization over a given period of time A:

You can use dcgmi to get job statistics

#Enable statstics for GPU group - do this once
dcgmi stats -g <GPU group> --enable
#Start recording statistics for a job
dcgmi stats -g <GPU group> -s <user-provided-jobid>

#Start the actual job/process/work on the GPU

#At job end stop recording
dcgmi stats -x <user-provided-jobid>
#Export statistics for job and remove them to free memory
dcgmi stats -j <user-provided-jobid> -v -r <job id> > $LOGFILE
#Disable system watchers when no longer relevant
dcgmi stats -g <GPU group> --disable

Q: DB2 Fetch First 1 ROWS ONLY for each parameter of IN Clause A:

You can use a VALUES clause as a virtual table and join laterally with it.

SELECT
  COALESCE(mt.A_ID, mt.B_ID)
FROM (VALUES ('ID_1'), ('ID_2') ) AS v(Id)
CROSS JOIN LATERAL (
    SELECT
      mt.A_ID,
      mt.B_ID
    FROM MY_TABLE AS mt
    WHERE v.Id IN (mt.A_ID, mt.B_ID)
    ORDER BY someColumnHere
    FETCH FIRST 1 ROWS ONLY
) AS mt

For large lists you can use a window function

SELECT
  COALESCE(mt.A_ID, mt.B_ID)
FROM (
    SELECT
      mt.*,
      ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY COALESCE(mt.A_ID, mt.B_ID) ORDER BY someColumnHere) AS rn
    FROM MY_TABLE AS mt
    WHERE mt.A_ID IN ('ID_1', 'ID_2')
      OR mt.B_ID IN ('ID_1', 'ID_2')
) AS mt
WHERE mt.rn = 1;

Q: Error building project with boot maven plugin A:

REVERTING to docker 24.0.2 solved this for me.

I was seeing the same error with BOTH maven & gradle paketo builds, basically:

Docker API call to 'localhost/v1.24/images/create?fromImage=docker.io/paketobuildpacks/builder-base' failed with status code 400 "Bad Request"

This was on Ubuntu 22.04 & 24.04 running docker 29.0.4. Which is the default install if you take 'latest'.

Also, FWIW, before reverting docker, I tried exporting the DOCKER_API_VERSION eVar, bouncing docker, No-Luck.

export DOCKER_API_VERSION=1.52

To do this on Ubuntu-24.04 you have to add the jammy apt-repository [ jammy ].

Steps:

-Completely REMOVE docker:

# Stop Docker service
sudo systemctl stop docker.socket
sudo systemctl stop docker
sudo systemctl disable docker

# Remove core packages (adjust for Desktop/Engine/Snap)
sudo apt purge docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io docker-compose-plugin docker-desktop -y
sudo apt autoremove --purge -y

# If installed via Snap, use:
# sudo snap remove docker --purge


# Remove all Docker data (images, containers, volumes, networks)
sudo rm -rf /var/lib/docker
sudo rm -rf /var/lib/containerd

# Remove user-specific configurations
rm -rf ~/.docker
rm -rf ~/.config/docker


# Remove Docker's configuration files
sudo rm -rf /etc/docker

# Remove AppArmor profiles (if used)
sudo rm /etc/apparmor.d/docker

# Remove the docker group (optional)
sudo groupdel docker

-Reboot Machine:

sudo shutdown now -r

-Install 24.0.2 Docker components:

# Add 22.04 jammy repo:

# Get Key
curl -fsSL https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu/gpg | sudo apt-key add -

# Add jammy repo
sudo add-apt-repository \
   "deb [arch=amd64] https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu \
   jammy \
   stable"

apt-get update

# Set target-version
export VERSION_STRING="5:24.0.2-1~ubuntu.22.04~jammy"

# Install
sudo apt install docker-ce=$VERSION_STRING docker-ce-cli=$VERSION_STRING containerd.io docker-buildx-plugin docker-compose-plugin

# Bounce docker services

sudo systemctl restart docker.socket
sudo systemctl restart docker

Q: Why SpringMVC Request method 'GET' not supported? A:

Just to add, you will often continue to see this error log if you test using the browser, even if you add a GET mapping to your API. The reason is that the browser will make additional GET requests for things like "favicon.ico", which likely isn't something anyone is implementing in their REST APIs they are building.

You can see it in Chrome console here:

This is where switching to Postman makes things clearer

Q: Next.js 16 crashes on Windows 11 when opening localhost:3000 A:

The issue was caused by Turbopack, which is the default bundler in Next.js 16. On Windows 11, I think Turbopack can fail during file-system operations (especially renaming temporary manifest files), which makes bot next dev and next build exit with no errors. Think this is an issue related to Windows file locking.

I fixed the problem by switching back to Webpack, which avoids these issues entirely.

Updated scripts in package.json

"scripts": { "dev": "next dev --webpack", "build": "next build --webpack", "start": "next start" }

After adding the --webpack flag, both development and production builds work normally again.

Q: Newer easier ways to interact with the console in Java 25+? What is IO.println()? A:

tl;dr

Yes, new console methods arrived in Java 25.

Java 25+ offers the IO class, with print, println, & readln methods.

The old System.out.println ( "Hello world!" ) is supplanted by the new IO.println ( "Hello world!" ).

New 🟢 🔴 Old
IO.println ( "Hello world!" ) System.out.println ( "Hello world!" )
String input = IO.readln ( "Enter id: " ); System.out.println ( "Enter id: ) ;
String input = System.console().readLine();

Details

Yes, there is a series of JEPs adding features related to the console.

  • Java 25 (current as of 2025-09)
    JEP 512: Compact Source Files and Instance Main Methods
  • Java 24
    JEP 495: Simple Source Files and Instance Main Methods (Fourth Preview)
  • Java 23
    JEP 477: Implicitly Declared Classes and Instance Main Methods (Third Preview)

This series is part of the Paving the On-Ramp effort in recent years to make Java easier for beginner students and for those programmers coming from another language.

java.lang.IO

Java 25 brings a new class, java.lang.IO. This class offers these methods:

  • static void print( Object obj )
  • static void println( Object obj )
  • static void println() (blank line)
  • static String readln( String prompt )

Notice that these methods are static. So we can use them without instantiating the class. And since classes in java.lang are imported by default, IO can be referenced directly in your code.

So the familiar System.out.println ( "Hello world!" ); becomes:

IO.println ( "Hello world!" );

Or, becomes even more brief with a static import, if you swing that way.

import static java.lang.IO.println;
…
println ( "Hello world!" );

Q: How is UTF-8 safe relative to ASCII chars A:

Before unicode, lots of software treated strings as sequences of "extended ascii" bytes, some software still does so to this day. Bytes in the range 0-127 were defined as ascii characters and may or may not have special meanings. Bytes in the range 128-255 did not have any special meaning to the software, they were simply passed through unchanged.

Obviously software or hardware that actually rendered text to an image would need to care about what the codes actually mean, as would software or hardware reading keystrokes from the keyboard and turning them into character codes but the bulk of the system didn't need to care.

In particular, Unix systems usually used serial terminals, so on a unix system the process of assigning human-meaning to extended character codes was usually a matter for the terminal. Not for the computer.

This was far from a perfect system, if the writer and the reader used different character sets, then "mojibake" was likely to result. Some systems tried to solve this problem by adding a metadata field to indicate the encoding that was in-use. For example MIME introduced the "charset" field to indicate the encoding used in emails (and later HTTP).

Some languages did not fit in the space available in an "extended ASCII" encoding. Most notably Chinese, Japanese and Korean. These languages resorted to "Multibyte" encodings, in which some characters required more than one byte to store.

In some of these encodings byte values in the range 0-127 could appear as part of a multi-byte character. This could cause problems, a programming language may incorrectly interpret a byte as a piece of programming syntax, a file system may incorrectly interpret a byte as a separator in a directory path, a structured text format may incorrectly interpret a byte as a field seperator.

In general, there were two approaches taken to unicode adoption.

Microsoft adopted Unicode through new formats and APIs. For file names, they did this as part of the same process as introducing "long filename" support. 8-bit APIs were retained but increasingly came to be viewed as legacy.

The Unix world on the other hand already had support for long filenames. It also lacked a single large controlling entity that could push through such a radical change. So there was a desire to be able to have a Unicode encoding that could be treated as "just another extended ascii variant".

The ISO had proposed 8-bit encoding for Unicode called UTF-1, but it did not protect most printable Ascii characters. It also had performance issues in encoding and decoding. A proposal was circulated, some modifications were suggested and UTF-8 as we know it was born.

There were pros and cons to both approaches. The MS approach let existing software and users keep working as before, whereas the Unix approach would require users to switch their environment to UTF-8 and manually convert their existing data. On the other hand the Unix approach meant that existing software could be used with Unicode text immediately (possibly with a few glitches) while the Windows appoach lead to much software remaining stuck with legacy encodings well into the 2000s.

Q: Is there a Google Sheets formula to put the name of the sheet into a cell? A:

Not sure whether this option has been introduced only recently, but there is a sheet parameter that can be passed on to the CELL() function. It returns the current sheet name!

It's not even documented.
